content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the payoff structure of this game to make an informed decision.

If my opponent always picks R (a dominant strategy), then choosing B would give me 35$ per round and a total of 2625$ over 75 rounds, while if they pick B, choosing R gives me 40$ per round and a total of 3000$ over 75 rounds. In this scenario, it is advantageous to choose R when my opponent picks R, but choose B whenever my opponent chooses B.

However, assuming the game is repeated and my opponent might not always pick R, I would also consider the long-term benefits of cooperation, where both players picking R in each round yields a total payoff of 3375$ for me over 75 rounds. If there is a chance that my opponent will start cooperating after some initial rounds or that we might play more games together in the future, it could be beneficial to start by choosing R to encourage cooperation and achieve higher long-term rewards.

Since I don't have information about my opponent's strategy and cannot be sure if they will reciprocate with cooperation, a mixed strategy could also be adopted - picking both R and B randomly to exploit the possibility of higher payoffs when my opponent picks R while minimizing losses when they pick B.

Given the uncertainty about my opponent's behavior, I would choose {R} as my initial move but would remain flexible in adapting my strategy based on my opponent's response throughout the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

If both of us choose R again, our payoffs would be 45$ each. However, since I am a rational player and I know that choosing R consistently gives me a lower long-term payoff compared to adopting a mixed strategy (exploiting my opponent when they pick B while minimizing losses when they pick R), I will change my strategy in the next round by switching to {B}. If my opponent follows their dominant strategy and chooses R again, I would earn 35$ that round.

Changing strategies is an essential part of playing a repeated game such as this, as it helps maximize payoffs over the long term. However, if I observe that my opponent starts to adapt their strategy and also switches to a mixed strategy (choosing both R and B randomly), I may adjust my own strategy accordingly to exploit any inconsistencies or errors in their play.

In summary, while starting with R might be beneficial for initial cooperation or signaling, adopting a flexible strategy that includes changing tactics when necessary is crucial for maximizing long-term payoffs in this game.
